name: Saint Philip the Apostle
shortDescription: Practical apostle from Bethsaida who calculated bread costs, found Nathanael, brought Greeks to Jesus, and asked 'Show us the Father'
longDescription:
Philip the Apostle stands among the Twelve as the practical disciple whose questions reveal profound theological depth. Called directly by Jesus with the words 'Follow me' (John 1:43), Philip immediately became an evangelist, finding Nathanael and declaring 'We have found him of whom Moses in the law, and the prophets, wrote‚ÄîJesus of Nazareth' (John 1:45). From the fishing village of Bethsaida on the Sea of Galilee, the same town as Peter and Andrew, Philip embodied the bridge between Jewish messianic expectation and Greek philosophical inquiry.

Three pivotal Gospel moments define Philip's character. When Jesus tested him about feeding the five thousand, Philip calculated practically: 'Two hundred pennyworth of bread is not sufficient for them' (John 6:7). When Greeks sought Jesus, they approached Philip first, recognizing in him a cultural bridge to the Greek-speaking world. Most profoundly, at the Last Supper, Philip voiced humanity's deepest longing: 'Lord, show us the Father, and it sufficeth us' (John 14:8). Jesus's response‚Äî'He that hath seen me hath seen the Father'‚Äîreveals Philip's question as the catalyst for one of Christianity's most important Christological declarations.

According to church tradition, Philip evangelized throughout Phrygia in Asia Minor, particularly in Hierapolis (modern Pamukkale, Turkey). He is said to have converted many through both preaching and miracles, including defeating a serpent worshipped as a deity. Tradition holds he was martyred in Hierapolis during the reign of Emperor Domitian, either by crucifixion or by being hung upside down. His tomb was reportedly discovered there in 2011 during archaeological excavations.

Philip represents the seeker who asks the questions others are afraid to voice, the practical mind that nevertheless yearns for divine encounter, and the bridge-builder between Jewish and Gentile worlds‚Äîforeshadowing the Church's universal mission.

etymology.derivation: From Greek 'philos' (loving) + 'hippos' (horse). A common Greek name indicating Philip may have come from a Hellenized Jewish family in the culturally mixed region of Galilee.

primaryLocation.name: Bethsaida
primaryLocation.description: Fishing village on the northern shore of the Sea of Galilee, hometown of Philip, Peter, and Andrew
primaryLocation.significance: Birthplace and hometown of three apostles; center of Jesus's Galilean ministry

associatedLocations.name: Hierapolis
associatedLocations.significance: Traditional site of Philip's martyrdom and burial; tomb discovered 2011

associatedLocations.name: Phrygia
associatedLocations.significance: Region of Philip's missionary activity in Asia Minor

associatedLocations.name: Jerusalem
associatedLocations.significance: Site of Last Supper where Philip asked 'Show us the Father'

geographical.culturalArea: Hellenistic Jewish Galilee, Roman Asia Minor

temporal.culturalPeriod: Second Temple Judaism / Early Christianity (1st century CE)

literaryReferences.author: John the Evangelist
literaryReferences.significance: Primary source for Philip's individual character and questions

literaryReferences.author: Matthew, Mark, Luke
literaryReferences.significance: Lists Philip among the Twelve Apostles

literaryReferences.author: Anonymous
literaryReferences.significance: Apocryphal text describing Philip's missions and martyrdom

biography.birthplace: Bethsaida, Galilee (fishing village on Sea of Galilee)
biography.earlyLife: Grew up in the predominantly Jewish but culturally mixed town of Bethsaida alongside future apostles Peter and Andrew. His Greek name suggests a Hellenized family, possibly connected to the fishing trade on the Sea of Galilee.
biography.calling: Called directly by Jesus with the words 'Follow me' (John 1:43). Immediately became an evangelist, finding Nathanael and testifying to the Messianic fulfillment of Moses and the Prophets.

majorEvents.description: Jesus found Philip and said 'Follow me' - one of only two disciples Jesus called directly (John 1:43)
Philip found Nathanael and declared 'We have found him, of whom Moses in the law, and the prophets, did write' (John 1:45)
When Jesus asked where to buy bread for 5,000, Philip calculated 'Two hundred pennyworth of bread is not sufficient' - Jesus testing his faith (John 6:5-7)
Greeks at the Passover feast approached Philip to see Jesus; Philip told Andrew, and together they brought the request to Jesus (John 12:20-22)
At the Last Supper, Philip asked 'Lord, show us the Father, and it sufficeth us' - prompting Jesus's declaration of unity with the Father (John 14:8-11)
According to tradition, Philip evangelized throughout Phrygia in Asia Minor, converting many and performing miracles
Tradition holds Philip was martyred at Hierapolis, either crucified or hung upside down, during the reign of Emperor Domitian (c. 80 CE)

achievements: One of the Twelve Apostles chosen by Jesus
First evangelist - immediately brought Nathanael to Jesus
Bridge between Jewish and Greek worlds
Asked the question that prompted key Christological teaching on Father-Son unity
Martyred for the faith at Hierapolis
biography.legacy: Philip is venerated as a saint in Catholic, Orthodox, Anglican, and Lutheran traditions. His feast day is May 3 (Western) or November 14 (Eastern). He is patron saint of hatters and pastry chefs. His relics are said to be in the Church of the Holy Apostles in Rome. Archaeological excavations at Hierapolis discovered what is believed to be his tomb in 2011.

coreConcepts.name: Practical Faith
coreConcepts.description: Philip's bread calculation shows faith engaging with material reality - not despising practical concerns but bringing them to Christ

coreConcepts.name: Evangelical Witness
coreConcepts.description: Immediately upon following Jesus, Philip found Nathanael - the pattern of disciple becoming witness

coreConcepts.name: Messianic Fulfillment
coreConcepts.description: Philip's declaration to Nathanael connects Jesus to 'Moses in the law and the prophets' - rooting Christianity in Jewish scripture

coreConcepts.name: Theophany Desire
coreConcepts.description: 'Show us the Father' expresses humanity's deepest longing for direct divine encounter

coreConcepts.name: Christological Revelation
coreConcepts.description: Philip's question prompted Jesus's declaration 'He that hath seen me hath seen the Father' - foundational for understanding Christ's divinity

coreConcepts.name: Jewish-Greek Bridge
coreConcepts.description: Greeks approached Philip to reach Jesus, indicating his role bridging Jewish and Hellenistic worlds

deities.name: Jesus Christ
deities.relationship: Master who called Philip directly; revealed Father-Son unity in response to Philip's question

deities.name: God the Father
deities.relationship: Philip asked to see the Father; Jesus declared seeing Him is seeing the Father

heroes.name: Saint Andrew
heroes.relationship: Fellow apostle from Bethsaida; together brought Greeks' request to Jesus

heroes.name: Nathanael/Bartholomew
heroes.relationship: Brought to Jesus by Philip; 'Israelite in whom is no guile'

heroes.name: Saint James the Less
heroes.relationship: Shares feast day May 3 in Western calendar

heroes.name: Philip the Evangelist
heroes.relationship: Different person - one of the Seven Deacons in Acts; sometimes confused in tradition

places.name: Bethsaida
places.relationship: Hometown shared with Peter and Andrew

places.name: Jerusalem
places.relationship: Site of Last Supper and 'Show us the Father' dialogue

concepts.name: Trinity
concepts.relationship: Philip's question about the Father led to revelation of Father-Son unity

concepts.name: Evangelism
concepts.relationship: Pattern of immediate witness - finding Nathanael upon being called

query.term: Philip findeth Nathanael Moses law prophets
Greeks Philip would see Jesus Andrew

seen me hath seen the Father
